headline: Gain a better understanding of the basics of nonverbal communication to help you become a more effective communicator.
description: This free online course in communication skills focuses on perception and nonverbal communication. It will help you understand the world around you, allowing you to view and hear things differently. You will study how to interpret facial expressions, the basics of auditory perception, and explore nonverbal communication skills including concepts such as space and gestures to help you become a more effective communicator.

courseDescription:
This course will begin by discussing perception, attention, and the different types of visual perception. You will learn that the way we view things affects our perception and that different cultures depend on different modes of communication. Today’s culture depends on visuals which have an effect on how we communicate. This course will discuss the move from text communication to images. You will also look into the problem of the simulacrum which is when the simulation appears like reality, for example, if a drawing appears lifelike.

You will then look into nonverbal communication in relation to emotion. According to one study, the percentage of the components of communication is messages at 7%, vocals at 38%, and nonverbals at 55%. With this course, you will also learn that in face-to-face communication, the verbal component consists of about 35%, and the nonverbal component is around 65%. You will also study how space is used in nonverbal communication, the importance of facial expressions to communication, and the difference between genuine and false expressions.

Improving your nonverbal communication skills will greatly enhance your personal life and career. With this free online course from Alison, you will easily gain a better insight into how our world can be perceived through visuals and sounds. You will learn the role of visual and aural perception in communication, including their relevance in the context of multimedia culture and new technologies. Check out this course and learn the art of nonverbal communication now!

• The key points from this module are:
  • Visual Culture and new technologies
    Visual culture has increased in importance with new technologies such as TVs, PCs, and screens. 
    Technology has been growing exponentially in the visual sphere.
    Modern life takes place on screen- our modern lives are mediated through screens.
    Reality is mediated by our senses, but modern technology has blocked our senses with a screen. This is experiencing reality second hand.
    Different cultures depend on different modes of communication, and today’s culture depends on visuals. This has an effect on how we communicate. 
    Limited space and screen size has resulted in the rise of text language, which has a lot of abbreviations. 

    The use of images in communication
    The existence of emoticons and images had raised the importance of images in today’s communication. 
    Mediation is anything that stands between an individual and reality. 
    The simulation of reality has become so advanced that it can cause you to question what is real and what isn’t.
    Avatars are characters which can interact with human beings. These monitors facial emotion and try and talk to the individual.
    The problem of simulacrum is when the simulation appears as reality, for example if a drawing appears lifelike. 
    Lightwave 8 creates images using sub-surface scattering techniques. 
    Visual culture is when we are submerged into visuals every day without realizing it.

• The key points from this module are:
  • Components of communication
    One study found that the percentage of components to communication are message (7%), Vocal (38%), and Nonverbal (55%).
    Context is relevant in changing how important each communication component is. 
    In face-to-face communication, the verbal component consists of about 35%, and the nonverbal component is around 65%.
    However, many studies overgeneralize and culture, learning, and behaviour are often not taken into account. 

    Culture and nonverbal communication
    There is debate over whether nonverbal communication is inborn or cultural. 
    Everyone uses body language either intuitively or conscientiously, but some are better than others at interpreting it. 
    Happiness, sadness, disgust, anger, fear, surprise, and scorn are all said to have been inborn rather than culturally taught. 
    However, culture can impact how we display these inborn emotions, for example in some cultures it is not ok for men to cry but it is ok for women to cry. 
    Gestures which communicate a specific meaning are known as emblems, for example putting your finger over your lips communicates silence. 
    However, the meaning of emblems can change or vary between cultures, for example the thumbs up symbol can mean ‘all ok’ or can mean superiority depending on the culture.
    Solitary gestures in isolation may be confusing, the context or cluster of symbols must also be considered. 
    Nonverbal communication can display power and social status much more effectively than verbal communication.
